messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 60 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Fast Hybrid Network Algorithms for Shortest Paths in Sparse Graphs

Paper Abstract: Abstract We consider the problem of computing shortest paths in hybrid networks, in which nodes can make use of different communication modes. For example, mobile phones may use ad-hoc connections via Bluetooth or Wi-Fi in addition to the cellular network to solve tasks more efficiently. Like in this case, the different communication modes may differ considerably in range, bandwidth, and flexibility. We build upon the model of Augustine et al. [SODA ‚Äô20], which captures these differences by a local and a global mode. Specifically, the local edges model a fixed communication network in which O‚Äã(1)ùëÇ1O(1) messages of size O‚Äã(log‚Å°n)ùëÇùëõO(\log n) can be sent over every edge in each synchronous round. The global edges form a clique, but nodes are only allowed to send and receive a total of at most O‚Äã(log‚Å°n)ùëÇùëõO(\log n) messages over global edges, which restricts the nodes to use these edges only very sparsely. We demonstrate the power of hybrid networks by presenting algorithms to compute Single-Source Shortest Paths and the diameter very efficiently in sparse graphs. Specifically, we present exact O‚Äã(log‚Å°n)ùëÇùëõO(\log n) time algorithms for cactus graphs (i.e., graphs in which each edge is contained in at most one cycle), and 333-approximations for graphs that have at most n+O‚Äã(n1/3)ùëõùëÇsuperscriptùëõ13n+O(n^{1/3}) edges and arboricity O‚Äã(log‚Å°n)ùëÇùëõO(\log n). For these graph classes, our algorithms provide exponentially faster solutions than the best known algorithms for general graphs in this model. Beyond shortest paths, we also provide a variety of useful tools and techniques for hybrid networks, which may be of independent interest.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 60 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 60"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Near-linear lower bounds for distributed distance computations, even in sparse networks",
        "Distributed coloring in sparse graphs with fewer colors",
        "Fast Construction of Overlay Networks",
        "o‚Äã(log‚Å°n)ùëúùëõo(\\log n)-time overlay network construction from graphs with out-degree 1",
        "Finding euler tours in parallel",
        "Distributed graph realizations, 2020",
        "Distributed computation in node-capacitated networks",
        "Shortest paths in a hybrid network model",
        "Spartan: A framework for sparse robust addressable networks",
        "Sublogarithmic distributed MIS algorithm for sparse graphs using Nash-Williams decomposition",
        "A simple and linear time randomized algorithm for computing sparse spanners in weighted graphs",
        "Near-optimal approximate shortest paths and transshipment in distributed and streaming models",
        "Centdian computation in cactus graphs",
        "Memory efficient algorithms for cactus graphs and block graphs",
        "A bounding box overlay for competitive routing in hybrid communication networks",
        "Fast approximate shortest paths in the congested clique",
        "Algebraic methods in the congested clique",
        "Optimal distributed coloring algorithms for planar graphs in the LOCAL model",
        "The features, hardware, and architectures of data center networks: A survey",
        "Channel allocation in wireless data center networks",
        "Data centers as software defined networks: Traffic redundancy elimination with wireless cards at routers",
        "Some algorithms on cactus graphs",
        "An Optimal Algorithm to Find Maximum and Minimum Height Spanning Trees on Cactus Graphs",
        "Computing shortest paths and distances in planar graphs",
        "Helios: a hybrid electrical/optical switch architecture for modular data centers",
        "A faster distributed single-source shortest paths algorithm",
        "Networks cannot compute their diameter in sublinear time",
        "Well-separated pair decomposition for the unit-disk graph metric and its applications",
        "Distributed algorithms for planar networks I: planar embedding",
        "Distributed algorithms for planar networks II: low-congestion shortcuts, mst, and min-cut",
        "Improved distributed algorithms for exact shortest paths",
        "Simple and near-optimal distributed coloring for sparse graphs",
        "Distributed monitoring of network properties: The power of hybrid networks",
        "Faster construction of overlay networks",
        "Time-optimal construction of overlay networks, 2020",
        "Augmenting data center networks with multi-gigabit wireless links",
        "An Introduction to Parallel Algorithms, volume 17",
        "A Parallel Algorithm for Computing Minimum Spanning Trees",
        "Competitive routing in hybrid communication networks",
        "Routing in unit disk graphs",
        "An overview of device-to-device communication in cellular networks",
        "Distributed graph coloring in a few rounds",
        "Computing shortest paths and diameter in the hybrid network model",
        "An optimal algorithm for solving the 1-median problem on weighted 4-cactus graphs",
        "A linear-time algorithm for solving the center problem on weighted cactus graphs",
        "Faster parallel algorithm for approximate shortest path",
        "Distributed approximation algorithms for weighted shortest paths",
        "Decomposition of Finite Graphs Into Forests",
        "Otakar Bor≈Øvka on minimum spanning tree problem: Translation of both the 1926 papers, comments, history",
        "Some simple distributed algorithms for sparse networks",
        "Distributed Computing: A Locality-Sensitive Approach",
        "Distributed algorithms for network diameter and girth",
        "Being fast means being chatty: The local information cost of graph spanners, 2020",
        "A survey on automatic configuration of virtual private networks",
        "Distributed verification and hardness of distributed approximation",
        "An Efficient Parallel Biconnectivity Algorithm",
        "Sd-wan: A modern hybrid-wan to enable digital transformation for businesses",
        "High-probability parallel transitive-closure algorithms",
        "C-through: Part-time optics in data centers",
        "Mirror mirror on the ceiling: Flexible wireless links for data centers"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 60 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Fast Hybrid Network Algorithms for Shortest Paths in Sparse Graphs, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
